title: Step 1 â€“ Project Overview
content: Goal: build a **Next.js 14 (App Router) + TypeScript** application. The app presents course steps from JSON, supports previous/next navigation with progress, a fade transition, and a theme toggle.

title: Step 2 â€“ Prerequisites
content: Install Node.js (v18+ recommended) and a modern code editor. Verify versions:
explain: If versions are outdated, install the latest LTS from `nodejs.org`.

title: Step 3 â€“ Scaffold Next.js
content: Create a new Next.js app (App Router) with TypeScript and start the dev server:
code:
npx create-next-app@latest next-lbd --typescript --eslint --app
cd next-lbd
npm run dev
explain: The --app flag enables the App Router. Open the URL shown in the terminal.

title: Step 4 â€“ Project Structure
content: Key files in a default App Router project. We will add a client component for the Toâ€‘do list and render it in app/page.tsx:
code:
app/
  layout.tsx
  page.tsx
  globals.css
components/
  TodoList.tsx  // client component
quiz: Where would you put shared UI (e.g., header/footer) in the App Router?

title: Step 5 â€“ Implement TodoList (client)
content: Create a client component with local state in components/TodoList.tsx and render it from app/page.tsx.
explain: We mark the component with 'use client' to allow state and events. Start with add/remove; later you can extend with persistence.

title: Step 6 â€“ Styling and UX
content: Style the app via app/globals.css or Tailwind. Keep content centered with readable typography. Optional: add a theme toggle with CSS variables.
quiz: How would you keep styles consistent across pages in the App Router?

title: Step 7 â€“ Run and Build
content: Run the development server and create a production build:
code:
npm run dev
# open http://localhost:3000

npm run build
npm start
explain: In production, npm start serves the built app. For Vercel, push to a Git repo and import the project.
